node.text:
This video will answer questions about raising a Highly Sensitive Child - ⁣
⁣
1:40 Q&A - How do I respond when my child cries over every little thing? ⁣
⁣
3:18 Q&A - How can you help your child name their emotions & why is this important? ⁣
⁣
4:05 Q&A - How do I help my child when they are embarrassed or ashamed? ⁣
⁣
6:33 - Q&A - How does being a Highly Sensitive Parent help? ⁣
⁣
7:30 - Q&A - My 3 year old Highly Sensitive Child hits his sister & then asks why he did it. Aren’t Highly Sensitive Children supposed to be empathetic? ⁣
⁣
9:05 - Q&A - How do you explain to other people that your child is Highly Sensitive? ⁣
⁣
10:20 - Q&A - How do I help my Highly Sensitive Child with a lack of confidence, especially socially? ⁣
⁣
12:13 Q&A - Is there anything I can do to help my child be less sensitive? ⁣
⁣
13:50 Q&A - my child has very big tantrums transitioning from daycare to home. I’ve tried everything! ⁣
⁣
16:20 Q&A - How do I deal with Highly Sensitive Teenagers? ⁣
⁣
⁣
#ResilientLittleHearts

node.text:
This video shares what High Sensitivity is, how you can identify it in your child, & how you can support them 💛⁣
⁣
0:35 What is high sensitivity⁣
⁣
3:13 For parents who aren’t highly sensitive themselves ⁣
⁣
6:15 Q&A - is high sensitivity genetic? ⁣
⁣
6:40 Q&A - can you see high sensitivity in newborns? ⁣
⁣
7:45 Q&A - my son is calm & controlled at school but loses it when he gets home. is this normal? ⁣
⁣
9:10 Q&A - what is Sensory Processing Disorder & how to deal with it? ⁣
⁣
12:43 Q&A - how do you deal with attention & focus issues with highly sensitive children? ⁣
⁣
14:42 Q&A - how do you build resilience in highly sensitive children? ⁣
⁣
16:10 the most important TRUTH about highly sensitive children ⁣
⁣
⁣
#ResilientLittleHearts

node.title: RAISING A HIGHLY SENSITIVE CHILD PT 1 //

node.text:
Here’s how to navigate your child’s behavioral issues 💛

Here’s what we covered: 

2.06 the pattern of behavioral issues in children during lockdown 

4:45 easing your parental anxiety 

5:40 for parents of children with additional needs 

7:26 how a child’s emotions connect to their behavior issues 

8:30 the BEST strategy to reduce negative behaviors with your child 

11:45 Q & A - dealing with toddler tantrums 

#ResilientLittleHearts

Due to the current situation in the world with the coronavirus, many people are experiencing fear. .
This video will share tips on how to help your children deal with fear 💛

node.title: HELPING YOUR CHILD DEAL WITH FEAR //

node.text: High sensitivity is a gift to steward within your child. Just like any gift there are strengths - tenderhearted empathy, intelligence, creativity & deep thinking. But highly sensitive individuals also typically struggle with anxiety more than the general population. Helping your highly sensitive child learn to overcome fear and anxiety is really important for their future...

node.text: Resilience is the capacity to overcome stress or challenge. It is a trait we all want to cultivate in our children. But it isn't going to just happen by itself, it is something we need to intentionally cultivate... #ResilientLittleHearts #TheBoyWhoStoodUpTall

The e-book is available this week wherever books are sold! #TheBoyWhoStoodUpTall

node.text:
It is often the children that we don’t understand, the ones who frustrate us & push us to our limits, that need the most love & support from us. 

Share your best tips below for connecting with a child who you’re struggling to connect with 👇🏼

#ResilientLittleHearts 

💛💛💛💛💛💛💛

We are taking some time away for summer vacation with our family & will be offline for 3 weeks… 

Here’s where you can find resources & support while we’re away: 

💛 Blog - we have a library of blog articles available on our website
(Links are in our bio & IG stories @resilientlittlehearts ) 
www.ResilientLittleHearts.com/blog 

💛 Free Resources - we have free guides & downloads on building resilience in children, raising highly sensitive children, & visual routine charts to communicate with your little ones. 
(Links are in our bio & IG stories @resilientlittlehearts )
www.ResilientLittleHearts.com/free-resources 

See you when we return 😘💛

May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'You cannot create teachable moments with children, during emotional meltdowns. Connect, allow the emotions to pass, & then you can teach. SARAH BOYD RESILIENT'.

node.text:
When your child is highly emotional, they aren’t looking for rational advice or “teachable moments”.⁣
⁣
⁣
They are looking for LOVE and CONNECTION. ⁣
⁣
⁣
So sit with them, hug them, be with them 💛⁣
⁣
⁣
Then once they are no longer in an emotional state, you will be able to talk about a rational solution to the problem. ⁣
⁣
⁣
#ResilientLittleHearts

Love is found in the messy, in the rupture & repair, in the staying, in dark moments, & in the tearful whispers of "I'm sorry"... SARAH BOYD RESILIENT'.

node.text:
Raising children is not easy undertaking… 

Many times we can feel as if we are making more mistakes, than we are doing things well. 

It can be easy to fall into the trap of viewing parenting almost as a task we need to perform perfectly at. 

It’s in these moments, we must gently remind ourselves that what’s most important is our LOVE & CONNECTION. 

Love & connection is still messy, & filled with many moments that we need to repair. 
But it is in our commitment to staying & repairing that we cultivate an emotionally healthy environment for our family. 

What do you compassionately tell yourself on the hard days of parenting? 👇🏼

#ResilientLittleHearts

node.text:
“From now on whenever I feel afraid, 
Or anxious, or nervous, or even dismayed,
I will stand up and stand up tall,
I will not crumble back into a ball.

For when I am brave & stand up to my fears, 
I will grow to be much bigger than what it appears, 
When I am bigger than what made me afraid, 
It will no longer seem scary & my fear will fade.” 

📖 excerpt from our children’s book about overcoming fear & finding courage #TheBoyWhoStoodUpTall 

Click the links in our IG stories or bio @resilientlittlehearts to get your copy 💛

Written by @sarahboyd 
Illustrations by @liseberleart 

#ResilientLittleHearts

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by RESILIENT LITTLE HEARTS®️ on June 29, 2021 tagging @sarahboyd. May be an image of text that says 'Empathy can be developed and grown, through curiosity & the imagination of someone else's experience. SARAH BOYD RESILIENT.'.

node.text:
Research shows that every individual is born with an innate level of empathy. 

Some children are just naturally more empathetic than others. 

But although empathy is skill we can be born with, it is also a skill we can CULTIVATE & DEVELOP in our children. 

Empathy is an foundational skill for children to develop as it’s an important part of
🌈 successfully navigating social situations & relationships, 
🌈 making good decisions,
🌈 adding a positive contribution to society. 

.
Empathy is grown through curiosity & taking time to imagine someone else’s experiences. 

You can develop empathy in your child through: 
💛 Reading books together 
💛 Hearing other people’s stories 
💛 Experiencing different cultures 
💛 Traveling to different places (hopefully in the future!) 
💛 Including perspective-taking in conflict resolution
💛 Asking “How do you think that might have made them feel?” 
💛 Asking “How would you feel in that situation?”

.
Note: deficits in empathetic behavior are a part of the diagnostic criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). This doesn’t mean that children with autism have no empathy, but rather have cognitive challenges recognizing & seeing things from another person’s perspective. 

#ResilientLittleHearts

node.text:
Teaching Your Child About Different Emotions 💛

Emotional literacy is being able to recognize & name different emotions. 

It is the foundation of emotional health & intelligence. 

We can start teaching our child to name emotions once they begin to talk. 

Start with the big 4 emotions:
🌈 Happy
🌈 Sad
🌈 Angry 
🌈 Scared 

As your child grows older (5+ years) you can introduce recognizing & naming more complex emotions. 

#ResilientLittleHearts 

.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Parenting can feel like a lot of pressure at times. 

In our current culture, the amount of areas you seem to need to master, in order to benefit your child, can be overwhelming... 

Remember, at the end of the day, all of parenting comes down to a relationship that you have with another little heart 💛

#ResilientLittleHearts

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by RESILIENT LITTLE HEARTS®️ on June 14, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'If you want your children to improve, let them overhear the the nice things you say about them to others. HAIM GINOTT RESILIENT'.

node.text:
Children want to know that they are wanted, valued and loved 💛

Our words have a profound influence on our relationship with them, & how they feel about themselves. 
How we talk with, & about our child, can either build a strong fabric of a relationship, or slowly tear it apart. 

.
This is not to say that parents shouldn’t share their challenges or negative feelings about parenting, with friends; but only to be mindful of context (& whether your child can hear you). 

This is also not saying that we need to be perfect with our words, as all parents have times we’ve said things we later regret. 
But when we own these words & apologize - it mends the relationship. 

🌿 Practical tip: keep a list of what you love about your child, & nice things they have done, in your notes app on your phone. 
You can use this list to remind you of the positives & encourage them with practical examples. 

#ResilientLittleHearts.
